title: WCAS AF_AM_ST 381-0-1 Topics in Transnational Black Studies

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce students to how the past is preserved and retold through archives and their absences. As an interdisciplinary course, we will investigate histories and theories of archives' construction and their function in societies. Our shared definition of an "archive" will range from repositories to memory to rituals to online outlets, and we will explore through discussions of how these different forms of preservation impact the histories that emerge from them. The course will conclude with an examination of different methods used for navigating the archive and its absences. The readings and discussions during those weeks will focus on recuperating the African diasporic past as a case study in those varying methods.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the semester, students will understand what is at stake in how history is preserved and written, and they will learn different techniques for addressing absences in their own narratives.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion of reading assignments and the occasional hands-on examination of archival material

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Class Discussion Posts (15%)
Primary Source Submissions (10%)
Four-page exploration of two collections at any archive (20%)
Midterm Class Presentation (25%)
Final Paper (30%)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Students will be reading excerpts from the following books:
Paula Byrne, Belle: The Slave Daughter and the Lord Chief Justice
Tina M. Campt, Image Matters: Archive, Photography and the African Diaspora in Europe
Jose van Dijck, Mediated Memories in the Digital Age
Caroline Frick, Saving Cinema: The Politics of Preservation
Ellen Gruber Garvey, Writing with Scissors: American Scrapbooks from the Civil War to the Harlem
Renaissance
Amelie Hastie, Cupboards of Curiosity: Women, Recollection, and Film History
Saidiya Hartman, Lose Your Mother: A Journey Along the Atlantic Slave Route
Toni Morrison, Beloved
Carla L. Peterson, Black Gotham: A Family History of African Americans in Nineteenth-Century
New York City
Ann Laura Stoler, Along the Archival Grain: Epistemic Anxieties and Colonial Common Sense
Diana Taylor, The Archive and the Repertoire: Performing Cultural Memory in the Americas
Michel-Rolph Trouillot, Silencing the Past: Power and the Production of History
Timothy B. Tyson, Blood Done Signed My Name
